notes.text:
Red Hat OpenShift Container Platform release 3.9.60 is now available with
updates to packages and images that fix several bugs and add enhancements.
notes.title: Topic

notes.text:
Red Hat OpenShift Container Platform is Red Hat's cloud computing
Kubernetes application platform solution designed for on-premise or private
cloud deployments.

This advisory contains the RPM packages for Red Hat OpenShift Container
Platform 3.9.60. See the following advisory for the container images for
this release:

https://access.redhat.com/errata/RHBA-2019:0027

This update fixes the following bugs:

* The rubygem-ffi 1.9.25 package reverted a patch, which allowed it to work on systems with SELinux `deny_execmem=1`, causing Fluentd to crash. This bug fix reverts the patch reversion and Fluentd now does not crash when using SELinux `deny_execmem=1`. (BZ#1655691)

* An incorrect role inclusion path was used in the scaleup playbooks. That error has been corrected and now the master scaleup works as it should. (BZ#1658453)

All OpenShift Container Platform 3.9 users are advised to upgrade to these
updated packages and images.
notes.title: Details

document.title: Red Hat Bug Fix Advisory: OpenShift Container Platform 3.9 bug fix and enhancement update

notes.text: A flaw was discovered in the HPACK decoder of haproxy, before 1.8.14, that is used for HTTP/2. An out-of-bounds read access in hpack_valid_idx() resulted in a remote crash and denial of service.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: haproxy: Out-of-bounds read in HPACK decoder
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text:
HTTP/2 support was added to haproxy in version 1.8, therefore OpenShift Container Platform (OCP) 3.7 and earlier are unaffected by this flaw. OCP 3.11 added a configuration option to ose-haproxy-router that made enabling HTTP/2 support easy, [2]. Prior to that, in versions OCP 3.9 and 3.10, an administrator had to customize the haproxy router configuration to add HTTP/2 support, [3]. OCP 3.9, and 3.10 are rated as moderate because HTTP/2 support was not a standard configuration option, and therefore unlikely to be enabled.

Versions of haproxy included in Red Hat Enterprise Linux 6 and 7, excluding rh-haproxy18-haproxy in Red Hat Software Collections, are unaffected as they package versions of haproxy before 1.7.

[1] http://www.haproxy.org/news.html

[2] https://github.com/openshift/origin/pull/19968

[3] https://docs.openshift.com/container-platform/3.10/install_config/router/customized_haproxy_router.html
notes.title: Statement

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.
notes.title: CVSS score applicability

remediations.details:
Before applying this update, ensure all previously released errata
relevant to your system have been applied.

See the following documentation, which will be updated shortly for release 3.9.60, for important instructions on how to upgrade your cluster and fully apply this asynchronous errata update:

https://docs.openshift.com/container-platform/3.9/release_notes/ocp_3_9_release_notes.html

This update is available via the Red Hat Network. Details on how to use the
Red Hat Network to apply this update are available at
https://access.redhat.com/articles/11258.

HTTP/2 support is disabled by default on OpenShift Container Platform 3.11. To mitigate this vulnerability keep it disabled. You can verify if HTTP/2 support is enabled by following the instructions in the upstream pull request, [1].

[1] https://github.com/openshift/origin/pull/19968

vulnerabilities.title: haproxy: Out-of-bounds read in HPACK decoder
